message: (kernel hacking, admin scripting, network programming, etc etc)
What would be the best operating systems book for a sys-admin?
What are you trying to learn to do?
@coderanger fundamentals, a better grasp on performance issues, maybe along the lines of this post on `ls` http://sysadvent.blogspot.com/2010/12/day-15-down-ls-rabbit-hole.html
Understanding the Linux Kernel (http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780596000028) was a good stepping stone for me in learning how low-level stuffs work
... but this topic is really for *any* highly recommended reading

To understand anything as a sysadmin, you really have to know how TCP/IP works on a deep level. Internetworking with TCP/IP by Comer is pretty much the bible here. TCP/IP Illustrated is a close second. http://www.amazon.com/Internetworking-TCP-IP-Vol-5th/dp/0131876716
Comer's book also covers a lot about how Ethernet and IP work together. Trust me, you'll learn more about being a good sysadmin after reading this book than any Linux or Windows book out there.
Mastering Regular Expressions is a great book for dev and sysadmin types.  http://oreilly.com/catalog/9781565922570
Also, Time Management for System Administrators http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780596007836 and Building Scalable Websites http://www.amazon.com/Building-Scalable-Web-Sites-Applications/dp/0596102356
